definitions: make changes and corrections to written or printed material to improve clarity and accuracy
reconsider and alter an opinion judgment or decision in light of new information
study material again especially before an examination to refresh knowledge
examples: The author carefully revised the manuscript before final submission
She revised her essay to include the professor's feedback
Scientists revised their theory after discovering new evidence
The company revised its forecast based on quarterly results
Students spent the weekend revising for their final exams
He revised his notes thoroughly before the important presentation

definitions: go back to a place that one has been to before especially after significant time
consider or discuss something again especially with fresh perspective or new information
examples: They revisited their hometown after twenty years abroad
The tourists revisited the museum to see the new exhibition
The committee will revisit this issue at next month's meeting
The author revisited themes from her earlier novels

definitions: give new life energy or vigor to something that has become weak tired or ineffective
examples: The new investment will revitalise the struggling downtown area
Fresh funding helped revitalise the community arts program
A good night's sleep revitalised her after the long journey
The renovation project revitalised the historic neighborhood completely

definitions: give new life energy or vigor to something that has become weak tired or ineffective
examples: The new mayor promised to revitalize the city's economy
Government grants helped revitalize the manufacturing sector significantly
The weekend retreat revitalized the exhausted team members
Fresh leadership revitalized the struggling nonprofit organization

definitions: bring someone back to consciousness or life especially through medical intervention
bring something back into use existence or popularity after period of decline
restore energy strength or vitality to someone or something that has weakened
examples: Paramedics worked quickly to revive the unconscious patient
The lifeguard revived the drowning swimmer with CPR
The director hopes to revive interest in classical theater
They're trying to revive the old tradition of harvest festivals
A cup of coffee revived him after the long night shift
The rain revived the wilting plants in the garden

definitions: officially cancel or withdraw a law license privilege or agreement making it no longer valid
examples: The court revoked his driving license after multiple violations
The university revoked the student's scholarship due to misconduct
The government threatened to revoke the company's operating permit
The board voted to revoke the controversial policy immediately

definitions: rise in rebellion against an established government or authority refusing to obey
cause someone to feel disgusted shocked or horrified by something unpleasant
examples: The colonists revolted against British rule in 1776
Workers revolted against the harsh new labor policies
The graphic images of violence revolted many viewers
The smell of rotten food revolted everyone in the room

definitions: change something completely and fundamentally especially by introducing new methods ideas or technologies
examples: The internet has revolutionized how people communicate globally
Smart phones revolutionized the mobile technology industry completely
This new treatment could revolutionize cancer therapy approaches
Assembly lines revolutionized manufacturing in the early twentieth century

definitions: move in a circular orbit around a central point or axis continuously
have something as the most important element or central theme focus
examples: The Earth revolves around the sun once every year
The wheels revolved slowly as the cart moved forward
Her entire life revolves around her children's activities
The discussion revolved around budget constraints and solutions

definitions: give something valuable or desirable to someone in recognition of their services efforts or achievements
examples: The company rewards employees with bonuses for exceptional performance
She rewarded the children with ice cream for good behavior
Hard work and dedication will eventually reward you with success
The university rewarded his research with a substantial grant

definitions: wind a tape or film back to an earlier point to replay or review
examples: Please rewind the video to the beginning of the scene
She rewound the cassette tape to hear the song again
Can you rewind the recording about thirty seconds please
He rewound the film to check the previous shot

definitions: make changes to something especially creative work to improve or update it significantly
examples: The designer had to rework the entire layout after feedback
She reworked the proposal to address the committee's concerns
The band reworked their old songs for the acoustic album
Engineers reworked the prototype to fix the design flaws

definitions: write something again especially in a different or improved way from the original
examples: The screenwriter had to rewrite the ending three times
She rewrote her essay to make the argument clearer
The journalist rewrote the article to meet the word limit
They're rewriting the software code from scratch completely

definitions: have or end with a sound that corresponds to another especially in verse
create verse or poetry using words with corresponding sounds at line ends
examples: The word 'cat' rhymes perfectly with 'hat' and 'mat'
These two lines don't rhyme as they should
Children love to rhyme when they're learning language skills
The poet rhymed every other line in the sonnet

definitions: tease or make fun of someone in a friendly joking manner without malice
examples: His friends constantly ribbed him about his new haircut
She gently ribbed her colleague about arriving late again
The teammates ribbed each other throughout the practice session
Don't take it seriously when they rib you like that

definitions: force cooked food through a ricer or sieve to create small grain-like pieces
examples: Rice the potatoes while they're still hot for best results
The chef riced the cauliflower as a low-carb alternative
She carefully riced the vegetables for the baby's meal
You need to rice the mixture before adding the cream

definitions: rebound off a surface at an angle especially of a bullet or projectile
examples: The bullet ricocheted off the metal wall dangerously
The ball ricocheted between several players before scoring
Stones ricocheted across the water's surface creating ripples
The sound ricocheted through the empty hallway eerily

definitions: free someone or something from an unwanted person or thing completely
examples: We need to rid the house of these persistent mice
The new manager rid the company of inefficient practices
She finally rid herself of all negative thoughts completely
They're trying to rid the garden of invasive weeds

definitions: make many holes in something especially with bullets piercing it throughout
speak in or pose riddles puzzles or deliberately obscure questions
examples: Bullets riddled the old wooden fence during target practice
The disease had riddled his body with painful lesions
The oracle riddled them with cryptic prophecies and warnings
Stop riddling and tell me what you really mean

definitions: travel in or on a vehicle being carried along as a passenger
sit on and control a moving animal especially a horse for transport
criticize or tease someone persistently in an annoying harassing manner
examples: She rides the subway to work every morning downtown
The children love to ride in their grandfather's truck
He learned to ride horses at his uncle's ranch
She rides her bicycle to school when weather permits
Stop riding him about his mistakes all the time
The boss rides employees who don't meet sales targets

definitions: form or mark with long raised lines or a series of ridges
examples: The wind had ridged the sand into parallel lines
Erosion ridged the hillside over thousands of years
The farmer ridged the soil before planting the potatoes
Heavy machinery ridged the muddy construction site surface

definitions: subject someone or something to contemptuous and dismissive language or behavior mockingly
examples: Critics ridiculed the mayor's proposal as completely impractical
The other children cruelly ridiculed his unusual accent
The press ridiculed the celebrity's fashion choices mercilessly
Don't ridicule people for trying something new and different

definitions: play a short repeated phrase in popular music especially jazz or rock
improvise creatively on a particular theme or idea in speech or performance
examples: The guitarist riffed brilliantly during the extended solo section
The bass player riffed on a classic blues progression
The comedian riffed on current events for twenty minutes
She riffed on the theme of identity throughout her speech

definitions: turn over pages quickly and casually when looking through reading material
shuffle playing cards by separating the deck and flicking edges together
examples: She riffled through the magazine looking for the article
He riffled the pages of the book searching for quotes
The dealer expertly riffled the cards before each hand
Learn to riffle shuffle properly for professional card games

definitions: search through something in a hurried way typically to steal or find something
examples: Thieves rifled through her desk drawers looking for valuables
Someone had rifled the office files during the weekend
He rifled through his pockets searching for spare change
The burglar rifled the jewelry box but found nothing valuable

definitions: set up equipment or machinery especially nautical equipment or temporary structures
arrange or manipulate something dishonestly to produce a predetermined outcome
examples: The crew rigged the sails before leaving the harbor
Workers rigged scaffolding around the building for repairs
They accused him of rigging the election results deliberately
The game show was rigged to favor certain contestants

definitions: form or act as an outer edge border or margin around something
examples: Mountains rim the valley on three sides creating protection
Dark clouds rimmed the horizon threatening an approaching storm
Gold rims the edges of these antique china plates
Frost rimmed the windows on the cold winter morning

definitions: cover something with frost or an icy coating especially in cold weather
examples: Freezing fog had rimed the trees with delicate ice
The cold morning rimed every surface with white frost
Winter weather rimed the ship's rigging making it dangerous
Ice rimed his beard after hours in the storm

definitions: make or cause to make a clear resonant sound of a bell
call someone on the telephone to communicate with them
surround or encircle something forming a complete circle around it
examples: The church bells ring every Sunday morning at nine
Please ring the doorbell when you arrive at the house
I'll ring you tomorrow to discuss the meeting details
She rang her mother to wish her happy birthday
Police officers ringed the building to prevent any escape
Mountains ring the ancient city providing natural defense

definitions: wash something with clean water to remove soap dirt or remaining substances
examples: Rinse the dishes thoroughly before putting them in the dishwasher
She rinsed her hair to remove all the shampoo
The dentist told him to rinse his mouth after treatment
Always rinse fresh vegetables before cooking or eating them

definitions: take part in a violent public disturbance by a crowd protesting against authority
examples: Angry citizens rioted in the streets after the verdict
Students rioted against the university's new policies last night
Prisoners rioted demanding better conditions in the overcrowded facility
The crowd began to riot when police arrived

definitions: tear or pull something quickly or forcefully apart or away from something
move rapidly and forcefully through space or along a path
examples: She accidentally ripped her dress on the sharp fence
Don't rip the package open so roughly please
The speedboat ripped across the lake at incredible speed
The storm ripped through the coastal town causing damage

definitions: become or make ripe mature and ready for harvesting or eating
examples: The tomatoes will ripen faster in direct sunlight outside
These bananas need a few days to ripen properly
Time and experience gradually ripened his judgment and wisdom
The cheese is ripened in caves for several months

definitions: form or cause small waves on the surface of water
spread gradually through a group or place like waves expanding outward
examples: The wind rippled the surface of the pond gently
Water rippled as the stone hit the surface
News of the scandal rippled through the small community
The economic effects rippled across the entire region

definitions: move from a lower position to a higher one going upward
increase in amount number intensity or degree over time
get up from lying sitting or kneeling to a standing position
examples: Smoke rises from the chimney on cold winter mornings
The hot air balloon rose slowly into the sky
Prices continue to rise despite government intervention efforts
Temperatures will rise significantly over the next few days
She rose from her chair to greet the visitors
The audience rose to give a standing ovation

definitions: expose someone or something to danger harm or loss by taking action
examples: Don't risk your health by ignoring the doctor's advice
She risked everything to start her own business
He risked his reputation by supporting the controversial proposal
Investors risk losing money in volatile market conditions

definitions: compete with someone or be comparable to them in quality or ability
examples: No other restaurant rivals this one for authentic Italian cuisine
Her artistic talent rivals that of professional painters
The two companies rival each other in technological innovation
This view rivals anything you'll see in Switzerland

definitions: fasten or join metal plates together using metal pins or bolts
hold someone's attention completely making them unable to look away or stop
examples: Workers riveted steel beams together constructing the bridge frame
The metal sheets were riveted to create the airplane fuselage
The speaker's dramatic story riveted the entire audience
She stood riveted to the spot unable to move

definitions: cut a horse's mane short so it stands upright from the neck
examples: The groomer roached the show horse's mane for competition
They decided to roach the pony's mane for easier maintenance
Many polo players roach their horses' manes for practical reasons
The stable hand carefully roached the stallion's thick mane

definitions: move about or travel aimlessly or unsystematically especially over a wide area
examples: Wild horses roam freely across the western plains
The children roamed through the woods exploring nature
Tourists roamed the ancient streets taking photographs everywhere
Her mind roamed to distant memories of childhood

definitions: make a loud deep prolonged sound like that of a lion or engine
shout something very loudly especially when angry or excited
examples: The lion roared fiercely warning other animals away
The motorcycle engine roared as it accelerated quickly
The crowd roared its approval when the team scored
He roared with laughter at the comedian's jokes

definitions: cook food especially meat in an oven or over a fire with dry heat
criticize or ridicule someone severely often in a humorous public way
examples: She roasted the chicken with herbs and lemon perfectly
We'll roast marshmallows over the campfire tonight
The comedian roasted the celebrity at the charity event
Critics roasted the director's latest film mercilessly

definitions: take property unlawfully from a person or place by force or threat
examples: Masked thieves robbed the bank yesterday taking thousands
Someone robbed him at gunpoint near the train station
Don't rob yourself of happiness by dwelling on negativity
High prices are robbing customers of their purchasing power

definitions: clothe or dress someone especially in long loose ceremonial garments
examples: The priests robed themselves in white for the ceremony
Assistants robed the judge before court proceedings began
The graduates were robed in traditional black academic gowns
She robed herself in silk before the royal reception

definitions: move gently back and forth or from side to side rhythmically
cause to shake violently with great force or impact
perform or dance to rock music with energy and rhythm
examples: She gently rocked the baby to sleep in her arms
The boat rocked gently on the calm water
The explosion rocked the entire neighborhood waking everyone
Scandal rocked the political establishment to its core
The band rocked the stadium with their greatest hits
Let's rock to this amazing music all night long

definitions: increase very rapidly and suddenly especially of prices costs or amounts
examples: House prices rocketed during the real estate boom period
Sales rocketed after the successful advertising campaign launched
The company's stock value rocketed following the announcement
Inflation has rocketed to its highest level in decades

definitions: move by turning over and over on an axis or surface
move forward on wheels or things that turn like wheels
form something flexible into a cylindrical or spherical shape by turning
examples: The ball rolled down the hill gaining speed quickly
The dog loves to roll in the grass outside
She rolled her suitcase through the airport terminal
The car rolled slowly to a stop at the intersection
Roll the dough flat before cutting out cookie shapes
He rolled the poster into a tube for storage

definitions: try to gain the love of someone through romantic gestures and attention
tell stories with exaggeration or imaginative embellishment especially about adventures
examples: He romanced her with flowers and candlelit dinners
The young man romanced his girlfriend throughout college
Don't romance the truth just tell me what really happened
He tends to romance his travel stories for effect

definitions: play roughly and energetically especially children or animals in a lively way
examples: The puppies romped in the yard chasing each other
Children romped through the playground during recess time
The team romped to victory winning by twenty points
We romped through the easy exam finishing in minutes

definitions: cover a building or structure with a roof for protection from weather
examples: They roofed the new house with cedar shingles last week
The contractor will roof the garage extension next month
Workers roofed the entire warehouse in just three days
We need to roof this shed before winter arrives
